name: NewYorker
text: The creator of “Bluey” said that his show intends to capture “the real, idiosyncratic way that kids play”—as opposed to the way that we adults imagine them playing. https://t.co/3OMzUp42Ll

name: NewYorker
text: "I noticed unaccustomed intensity in my responses to the art works that I encountered, taking them in like gulps of air after escaping a miasma," Peter Schjeldahl writes, about visiting a newly reopened sculpture park. https://t.co/mGVGx8wDbp

text:

text:

name: NewYorker
text: “It was unimaginable that New York would not have theatre, would not have shows on Broadway, and crowds in Times Square every night,” John Lithgow says. Nevertheless, there have been some fascinating attempts at “virtual theatre.” Watch here. https://t.co/Rv0OMF5o8j

name: NewYorker
text: "Anybody who knows me knows that I want to do right by everyone, so to learn that my actions—specifically, eating humans—were ever at anybody’s expense makes my heart hurt." https://t.co/xB708MEwT6

name: NewYorker
text: On #NewYorkerRadio, the journalist and historian @Isabelwilkerson talks with David Remnick about how America’s racial hierarchy should be thought of as a caste system, not unlike the one that dominated in India. https://t.co/YKiwRAfQE8

name: NewYorker
text: In her poetry, Alice Oswald seeks to translate the atmosphere of Homer’s epics. https://t.co/XZP2kfvNkM

text: Silvia Rosi photographs the work of the designer Grace Wales Bonner, whose clothing is “as disciplined as it is lush,” Hilton Als writes. https://t.co/cMCb3Fdox0

name: NewYorker
text: There’s a striking mix of normalcy and trauma in the new short documentary “Last Days at Paradise High,” which follows high schoolers in Paradise, California, after the devastating Camp Fire. Watch here. https://t.co/UYGxgrikNl

name: NewYorker
text: While there are a number of “digital wellness” apps to help people manage their screen time themselves, their main drawback is that they won’t punch you in the face. https://t.co/YrVlMVf80b

text:

name: NewYorker
text: The German pianist Igor Levit is used to playing carefully chosen programs at concert halls all over the world. At home, he can choose whatever pieces ﬁt his mood. https://t.co/1j2avR37lL

name: NewYorker
text: The U.S., with only four per cent of the world’s population, has more than 25 per cent of the world’s known COVID-19 cases. For the majority of them, the point of infection is unknown. https://t.co/jav76ecwFd

name: NewYorker
text:
In a series of iPhone photographs taken over the course of two and a half years, Jeff Mermelstein captures the quotidian dramas taking place on the phone screens of unsuspecting strangers.

https://t.co/Sb1Agx5Kob

text: “Tenet” is a $200 million charm bracelet, strung with one shiny set piece after another, Anthony Lane writes. https://t.co/4g8Mq0QZOj
